title: The Fall of the Berlin Wall
key_facts: Constructed in 1961 by the GDR (East Germany) to stop mass emigration to the West.
Stood as the most prominent symbol of the 'Iron Curtain' dividing Europe.
Fell on November 9, 1989, after a botched press conference by GDR official Günter Schabowski.
Led to the formal reunification of Germany on October 3, 1990.
causes: Mass protests in East Germany (Monday Demonstrations) demanding freedom and travel rights.
Reforms in the Soviet Union (Glasnost and Perestroika) under Mikhail Gorbachev.
The opening of borders in Hungary and Czechoslovakia, allowing East Germans to flee to the West.
outcome: The end of the division of Germany and the collapse of the GDR.
Accelerated the fall of communist regimes across Eastern Europe.
Symbolized the beginning of the end for the Soviet Union and the Cold War.

figures.name: Mikhail Gorbachev
figures.role: Soviet Leader whose non-intervention policy allowed the wall to fall
figures.significance: Refused to send Soviet tanks to crush protests.

figures.name: Günter Schabowski
figures.significance: Accidentally announced immediate border opening, triggering the rush.

figures.name: Helmut Kohl
figures.significance: Architect of the rapid German reunification process.

impacts: Reunification of East and West Germany into a single democratic state.
End of the Cold War geopolitical order.
European integration and the expansion of the European Union.
sources: Sarotte, M. E. (2014). The Collapse: The Accidental Opening of the Berlin Wall.
Taylor, F. (2006). The Berlin Wall: A World Divided, 1961-1989.
